author: BatMeckley
content:
Been working on this MPC Studio all day today, and was struck by how lucky I am to be a part of this server. Last night I had a question about an audio routing program and multiple people that are not on my payroll, they do not work for me or owe me anything, responded not just same day but within minutes with information that helped me get to where I was trying to go.

So many producers/writers/engineers/music makers/ dreamers are going to be better off, and way further along their paths, because of the wealth of knowledge and the generosity of the people on this discord, from the most seasoned mods to the newest noobs. And it’s entirely free. 

Thanks @oaklandmatt for putting this thing together. There’s always something new to learn and this is a rad place to learn it.

author: BatMeckley
content:
No. 
No no. 
No to the hell nah no. 
This is why I keep telling people how important it is to develop their taste. 
Alex shares similar sonic traits with his Dad because he grew up listening to someone go, “Christ there’s so much wooliness in this vocal, we need to get it up to where the audience can hear the words” or “let’s cut some space HERE in the track so that THIS sits”. The whole secret is the WHY, not the fact that he gifted him a MH Channel strip license. 

I’ve been really into photography lately, and I’m constantly struck by how my professional photographer little brother constantly gets better results than i do on worse gear. And it’s because he knows what to look for in a photograph, and then it’s easy enough to work backwards from there. That’s the skill of the whole thing. And it’s such a strong parallel to watching the Machine Head collectors on gearspace or the $12k PRS blues lawyers on TGP wax poetic about gear while clearly having no idea what the gear is actually used for. 

Focus on the right things.

author: bobby k
content: In the midst of a kinda unique side quest at the moment - label pulls me in at an hourly rate with an artist (and good friend) that I’ve mixed for many times because the production sessions were such a mess that they felt like they couldn’t even finish the records until some light mixing and organization took place. Songs spread out between multiple project files, DAWs, laptops…vocals tracked to mp3s with the ~50ms delay thing…Some of these producers templates…brilliant stuff. Saw one vocal travel through maybe 7 or 8 auxes and hit probably 4 different rvox’s along the way. It was like a labyrinth of signal flow that was nearly impossible to follow (and once I deleted half the auxes and waves plugins, it started to come back to life). In short they’re having me un-mix it, hand it back for some more production, then do the final mixes later this year. A true testament to the importance of organization and more importantly minimalist, straight forward session files. I wonder how often this need comes up and how feasible it is to be involved ahead of the handoff as a mixer these days. And before you frown at me for griping, this is an absolutely incredible project, many insanely talented musicians I respect. Very right brained, free flowing group. So it felt cool to be able to play more of a part on the project as the more left brained participant and see the stress relief happen in real time.

author: bobby k
content:
Most of my years in music have felt like groundwork-laying years. Just because your credits playlist isn’t looking the way you’d like doesn’t mean that growth wasn’t happening. I would challenge you to reflect on where you started 2025 and where you are now and take inventory of what growth or lessons you experienced. 

The most rewarding bits of this year for me wouldn’t make sense to post about. Paid off my first business loan. Improved the efficiency of signal flow in my studio. Learned to fix some gear. Stood up for myself in a hard conversation with some assholes trying to rip me off. Got out of the UAD ecosystem. 

None of that I’m posting about or adding to a playlist, but it feels just as essential (or more) to my business than the songs that got released.

author: LAPhill
content:
I don't know why I didn't think of this sooner, but the closest parallel to the seismic shift of AI might be samples, even more so than things like digital recording or Pro Tools. When Hans Zimmer recorded an orchestra and started writing music with a DAW and showing clients mockups, nothing was ever the same. For a long time (even now!) the pencil-and-paper people griped about how it wasn't real composition. Orchestras feared that they would all be replaced by computers. But ultimately, everyone had to come to terms with the new world order and adapt. There was a period in the mid-90s through mid-late 2000s where orchestral writing was reduced to nothing more than long notes and short notes. All of the nuance was gone, because the tech couldn't handle it yet and people blamed the tech. Many mourned the loss of true orchestral writing, yearning for a by-gone era. 

But eventually, people learned to harness these new tools and they met the technology on its own terms. People are doing wildly innovative things with samples now, we've moved completely past the era of "can I make a convincing clarinet come out of my keyboard?" Orchestras and live musicians have not been replaced. Sure, the process is different than it used to be, but that's how innovations work. All of us would be living very different lives without samples of drums, guitars, orchestras, synths, etc. There will be a generation coming up where AI is already a thing, they won't have ever lived in the before-times. Just like those here who've never cut to tape. It's okay.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Not sure how long you feel like you've been in this state, but it kinda sounds like you're describing the place just before it's your lyrics and arrangements on NMF. 

It's hard to draw parallels because I came up pre streaming and there's just a lot more people making records. But I had my first 3-4 things that started getting attention get taken away from me by managers/ labels/ bigger producers/ bigger mixers. Once I got to that next level it was obvious why I wasn't the guy yet. But if you're working on things that are at some point getting out there in a real way, that's the place that most people are before they jump up. 

Some of it is opportunity, some of it is skillset, some of it is time management (if you're hustling, it helps to turn great shit around before everyone else), and some of it is just the intangibles that come from more reps. 

My One Direction song came out 17 years after I first recorded the first band I was in. I'm not recommending anyone spend 17 years doing something all the time for no real money. But that's how it went for me.

author: Rollmottle
content: I manage a team of younger folks in my day job and there are a ton of parallels with music. One of things that frustrates me to no end is the belief that there's a "How to" checklist for how to get good. The answer is there is no answer and it looks different for everybody. I can certainly tell you the principles and strategies for how you might get good. But you need to find your own way and do the work. And sometimes that is quite literally grinding until you break through. People don't like hearing that there really is no answer (and they think you're being a dick for telling them there isn't one...which is a whole other thing). I think the ubiquitous accessibility of information has trained a generation to expect answers to be a Google or one weird trick away.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: Rollmottle
content: Focusing on the things squarely within my control is the way I’ve learned to do it. Only I can choose where and how to focus my attention and energy. The "world" doesn't make me do or feel anything I don't choose to feel or do. This doesn’t mean tune out and become a cold-hearted sociopath. But we need to balance the inputs so we are maximally available to the pursuits and the community we will have an immediate impact on. The world doesn’t give a shit if I constantly bang on about <insert anything bad you can think of here>. But my wife or child or collaborator or co-worker certainly will. We have so much more control over our perceived realities than we give ourselves credit for. And it's our choice whether we indulge the negative.

author: Rollmottle
content: I've been a software designer for almost 25 years and still do it. Been running a label, making/releasing music and doing mixing and mastering for that whole time as well. About 3 years ago it clicked that mastering is my thing and decided to spend the last few years dialing in my rig and room around mastering. The job has been able to subsidize what has turned into a parallel career. I have designs on having this be my full time gig at some point, but I'm taking it slow, honing my craft and building my client base and studio while the steady paycheck is there. It's nice to be able to do that without grinding to make ends meet. I realize that is a privileged position to be in so I am grateful. With COVID, I can also crank out masters while I WFH when there's downtime or I need a work break. Some weeks are harder than others from a workload standpoint, but mastering is part of my brain-therapy so I'm happy to take it all on.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve been using a nice workflow for AirPod checks recently.

1. Have an output from your monitor/output bus (I have it on a send in my template) to PT Bridge

2. Open QuickTime and open a new audio recording (Cmd + shift + N). 

3. Select PT Bridge as the QuickTime audio input. Turn up the volume slider to monitor

4. Select AirPods as system output 


Hey presto. Works great, no need to stream to phone etc. Just have to remember to turn down that QuickTime volume slider when you flip back to speakers. Also I occasionally accidentally start QT audio recording with spacebar when meaning to hit play in Tools. No biggie 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: ehutton21
content:
Piggy backing on a lot of the great thoughts in here and recalling my own musical education, I would say dividing the curriculum into a “listening” component and a “creating” component would be critical. In hindsight, it was incredibly formative for me that ear training practice and actual theoretical/sheet music knowledge always came alongside the practical element of sitting at keys and performing the pieces I was assigned that week.

I like the idea of breaking down modern pop structure, I like the idea of covering signal flow a lot. I think you can teach and test signal flow in theory while allowing someone to practice their recording technique by mimicking the song structure of their favorite pop song. I’m not proposing that as an actual coursework suggestion (I doubt most would be ready for that week one) but just as a thought for course organization

author: David Fuller
content:
OK let's start with the basics. 

A capacitor in series acts as a 6dB/oct high pass filter, with the corner frequency dependent on the value of the capacitor. In parallel, it acts as a low pass filter.  An inductor does the opposite of a capacitor - high pass in parallel, low pass in series. These, along with resistors, are the basic "building blocks" of a passive filter network.

author: peterlabberton
content:
K, so, I’m not a mastering engineer, and I know that’s not exactly the focus of this group, but I’m curious to hear some of the most experienced folks on here (i.e. @cian riordan @oaklandmatt and I’m sure others I don’t know about!) chime in on loudness in 2021. For instance, I love love love Jaime by Brittany Howard, and Shawn is phenomenal (AND if shit sounds great who cares what the LUFS meter says), but it is loud as hell. With streaming theoretically leveling the playing field a bit, what are you guys looking for when you get a record mastered? Is there someone mastering right now who is just boldly NOT slamming a limiter and letting things breathe more? Do we care?

I ask partly because, like I think many people, I incorporate a limiter on my mix bus to get things loud and be mixing “into” a mastering chain, and this has led me down a bit of a rabbit hole.

author: dylannash
content:
What are some of your favourite elements of your prod/mix templates? I currently have a separate production/writing template and then another for mixing but I’m trying to hybridise and streamline them a little more to get faster results and hopefully focus on the song. Also, most of the songs I mix tend to be one’s I’ve written and produced as well, so hoping to cut down on session set-up time.

Some of mine are an instant “duck bus”, which I picked up from Ian Kirkpatrick. It’s a pre-loaded aux with something like LFO Tool or shaper box on it, so you can quickly route and uniformly make things side chain.

Another quick workflow thing I love is having Pro Tools audio playlists with a bunch of reverse sweeps, impacts and other transition fx/ear candy hidden and ready to go in the session, so you can quickly try out a bunch. 

I also have the trim plugin added as the first and last plugin on every new track preset, as I use them to quickly manage the gain in and out of each track and so I don’t have to search for them constantly.

Ozone Spectral shaper on some music busses and as a replacement for Soothe on the mix bus has also been a real win (thanks Jon!) Although these sorta things aren’t turned on whilst writing as they have a ton of latency.

Keen to hear what you all find useful!

author: Eric Martin
content: I route my mix bus to a print bus and can use this as a ref A/B by toggling the input, then if I have a ruff mix or a ref I can choose the playlist of which one then I never process on a master, always mix bus process and print to the print bus, that way I can hear and SEE my mix getting printed in real-time as a check to make sure everything “looks” right as it sounds right

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can't stop thinking about this idea of "Why don't you play something that people actually like?"

I personally wrestle a lot with the idea of making music *for* other people. It's simply not very high on my list of priorities. I'd say I'm self-centered in how I approach making music. I'm out to make stuff that *I* want to hear. Things that aren't being represented elsewhere. Flavors I've never heard. I'm not aiming for a broad appeal, but I'm also not shying away from it. I'm just not much of a people pleaser in that regard. I'm in it for the discovery and the exploration and the pleasure of making something that excites me.

I think often about that Steve Jobs sentiment of "People don't know what they want until they see it." I think about that a lot. I trust that if I follow what feels good to *me* then I'll get something valuable out of it, and maybe it'll connect with others. If not, that's alright too. I'll know that I've made something that feels great.

I sometimes worry about this because I've always felt that it puts me at odds with a lot of people out here trying to make excellent records. Sometimes our goals will align, but I just don't feel motivated by the need to appeal to a lot of people and that can also make us diverge.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that there's a different kind of taste that I'm trying to cultivate. It's one that runs parallel to the kind of taste that is good at appealing to a large number of people. I feel as if I'm aiming at an entirely different goalpost from people playing the other game. I want to tickle people in a way that they didn't know they were capable of. That's what's thrilling to me.

author: David Fuller
content: The last filter in the Pultec is the LF boost/cut. The low cut has its capacitor bank connected in series to the output; The low boost has them connected in parallel with the output, with the output going to ground. Both are again acting as very broad shelving filters, though with *slightly* different center frequencies - which is why the "pultec LF trick" exists

author: Deleted User
content:
I only agree halfway. 

What does more value mean in art? How can you be more valuable than to make better music? All of that is vague. 
We all are working on being better, but not all of us are good. 

Those who aren’t good won’t make money- but I think those who are decent should make at least good part time income. 

How good you are is only quantifiable with stream counts. One stream count isn’t more valuable than the other. There isn’t really a straight parallel in what it means to be valuable. 

A song that saved someone’s life from suicide is a one stream count, a song that you didn’t know was playing while the phone was muted is also one stream count. they are both worth $.00437. I’m not saying a song that saved life should make more money. But was that more valuable than a song streamed while the phone was muted? Clearly it is

author: Deleted User
content: well… that is my point. value’s not really parallel to the money

author: Deleted User
content:
how our clients come up with money to pay us is important in order to stay sustainable. because we’re technically in a business of helping another business (artists or labels) make money. 

huge part of our values are tied to our ability to make them money. so of course it matters. 

And our ability to make them money isn’t directly parallel to how good we are at what we do. If they made money, it’s probably because everyone in the team nailed it. But if it’s not making money- that’s not because we sucked at our job. 

Which is why I started getting more involved in artist branding, I wish I could offer enough insights in building a fan base and marketing side of things. Because then I can really be more in control of the situation. 

but even then- there’s not enough money in the market. there’s a long and steep valley of despair between climbing from bottom to top. I do think if there was more money in the pool, the valley of despair wouldn’t be that bad. and in order to pull more money in, crowdfunding could be one of the ways. I wish I can come up with more solutions…

Shawn Everett’s tape / match eq technique ….that jacquire king kick/bass vu meter balance thing , the andy Wallace ambient drum triggers ….schepps and his dual mono 1176 back bus 🚎 ….even al Schmitt in capitol mixing with no eq …..these have all been really inspirational ideas and convos I’ve seen from there . At this point they’ve got so much content on there bro ….and even the JJP don’t send me 48 kHz files convo 😂. What’s not to love

author: spectrummasters

TIP O my hat to the-electrical  engineers

author: spectrummasters
content: 😂 interesting reactions gents . Re rhe caps…..one of my goals is to be able to read a schematic for one of these and understand the physics and electrical processes at work . IMHO they are like a maze of genius . I’m caught up in the concept that electrical engineers were tapped into musical needs and concepts so much that they made legacy mysical momentd possible ( Ye olde Phil Collins SSL LMC drums scenario etc ) . Decades later in the digital world of an instant studio in a box, it’s not really obvious that some super bright tech came up with the routing ideas and then created the electrical circuitry for it . And then these techs would sort of partner the recording / mix engineers in a sort of perfect marriage of art and science . Love it !

author: markmaclure
content:
That is 100% the answer it’s just really tricky to implement. I suppose you could filter out everything above the fundamental of the bass/mix/whatever and build parallel harmonics off that fundamental, but it gets tricky adding them back in without it getting phasey. You would also have to be very specific about which harmonics you add back in so they don’t stick out too much. 

This is super interesting to me because the fundamental that is perceived isn’t actually there! So it could have big potential for headroom/loudness if I could understand this better. 

However, I’m also hearing Ruari’s voice in my head asking me if this is worth the deep dive or if it’s just better to just use Rbass and get on with making songs haha

author: Rob Domos
content:
I once had an ilok die the day I bought it and then another one died a month into me having it. After both of those happened I swore off ilok for while and friends swore to me that they never had a problem and said it must be user error. 

After some reading, it turned out that there was an undisclosed problem with bus-powered hubs killing them and I had been connecting them with a bus powered hub, so I gave ilok one more go and connected it straight to my mac and I haven’t had a problem in years

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
A lunch this weekend brought to mind the parallels between servers and our various jobs as record makers

A completely neutral and personality free server gets the job done, but doesn’t elevate the experience, doesn’t bring that warmth

At the other extreme some servers make it all about themselves, regaling you for 5 minutes with a personal anecdote while the entree goes cold

Assuming competence at the job neither of these extremes seem optimal

author: Calvin Lauber
content: If you print your mix to a final stereo track, I will change the input of that track from whatever master bus output , to “MON L/R “ - which is the direct feed output of the Apollo. Then I mute that track and hit play on Apple Music (normalization off!) to print. I just record reference tracks straight in as part of the playlists of final mixes, that way when I’m in input mode I’m listening to my mix, and when I take it out I hear the reference. Instant A/B

author: popthetrunk
content: Like @Bryan DiMaio said, the MacOS scaling is great. In general you want more ppi(pixels per inch) for better quality, you can figure that from the screen size and resolution. I have a 57” 4k tv I’ve used as an aux display before at ~8’ that’s pretty good. The default scaling(HD) is fine for most audio work at that distance, but would probably go down a notch scaling wise for extended text/admin stuff or get a bigger tv. You need HDR on the tv and to enable in system prefs for it to look right with the scaling, otherwise it’s a bunch of banding and moire that’s really annoying ime.

That was certainly my first impression clicking about. I feel like it has a lot of promise, but was quite cumbersome to integrate and very clunky, I just think most software should be pretty intuitive to get going. I loved the idea of getting into it for the speaker management stuff, access to plugins etc. amazing on paper. I simply want to have 4 discrete paths to my ATC’s and stereo subs and it wouldn’t let me customize a simple 4ch layout to do that where it would enable bass management panels to handle crossovers. Your point about additional latency was also very well noticed. Really could be great
